'''Gender-blind''' (or '''unisex''') is a term describing activities undertaken and services provided without regard to the [[gender]] of those who participate.
== Choice of words == ''Unisex'' is an older term, and a [[misnomer]] meaning "one sex". A more appropriate term would be bisex (which would mean two sexes). It should not be confused with [[bisexuality]]. ''Gender-blind'' however goes against most tenets of [[heteronormativity]] by not looking at gender at all.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
== The National Student Genderblind Campaign ==
In 2006 the [http://www.genderblind.org National Student Genderblind Campaign] was created as a collaborative grass-roots organization intended to educate [[college]] students, administrators, and others throughout the [[United States]]. The NSGC advocates for the implementation of gender-inclusive [[dormitory|dorm]] room and [[washroom|bathroom]] options.
==Mixed-gender hospital rooms==
The use of mixed-gender hospital rooms has proved controversial in both [[Great Britain]] and [[Canada]].<ref>John Miner, Shared room sparks rage,London Free Press, June 17, 2010</ref> Manitoba's Health Minister, [[Theresa Oswald]], has campaigned actively against such rooms after receiving complaints from a Winnipeg patient, Ollie Ingram.<ref>Bruce Owen, Oswald vows action to stop coed rooms in hospitals, Winnipeg Free Press, May 14, 2010</ref> Oswald said if humanity can "put somebody on the moon," it can find a way to honor gender requests without leading to delays for patients.<ref>Bruce Owen, Oswald vows action to stop coed rooms in hospitals, Winnipeg Free Press, May 14, 2010</ref> At the same time, some medical ethicists have been critical of efforts to return to single-sex rooms.<ref>Bruce Owen, Oswald vows action to stop coed rooms in hospitals, Winnipeg Free Press, May 14, 2010</ref> [[Jacob Appel]], an advocate for mixed rooms in the [[United States]], has written that opposition to gender-mixed rooms stems from "old-fashioned prejudice" and argues that: "Because some people have been brought up to fear or dislike sharing a room with a person of the opposite sex, or blush at the prospect of catching a glimpse of an unwelcome body part when a robe slips open, we enshrine and perpetuate this prejudice in social policy.<ref>Jacob Appel, Are We Ready for Coed Hospital Rooms? ''Huffington Post'', June 18, 2010</ref> Great Britain has agreed to phase out such rooms by 2010.<ref>John Miner, Shared room sparks rage,London Free Press, June 17, 2010</ref>
